entry.title: Radio Days
entry.content: 🎥 Radio Days, 1987 ⭐️ ★★★★½ There’s never a dull moment in Radio Days. A warm, funny, and beautifully woven love letter to a bygone era. The ensemble cast is excellent across the board, with fun appearance by Mia Farrow and a song by Diane Keaton. The film floats effortlessly through 90 minutes of pure nostalgic joy. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/radio-days/1/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Milli Vanilli
entry.content: 🎥 Milli Vanilli, 2023 ⭐️ ★★★★ Rob & Fab come out of this film almost unhurt, if not entirely cleared. Charles Shaw, on the other hand, comes off pretty badly, acting like the guy who broke a deal he once benefited from, then cried foul when the spotlight turned elsewhere. Altogether, a good documentary on an astonishing and messy moment in pop culture. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/milli-vanilli/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Evil Under the Sun
entry.content: 🎥 Evil Under the Sun, 1982 ⭐️ ★★★★ Peter Ustinov is at his most charming as Poirot. Supporting turns from Diana Rigg, Maggie Smith, and Denis Quilley are pitch-perfect. Cole Porter soundtrack is an inspired choice, beautifully reorchestrated to match the film’s vintage glamour. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/evil-under-the-sun/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Birdcage
entry.content: 🎥 The Birdcage, 1996 ⭐️ ★★★★ Nathan Lane is a whirlwind of emotion and timing, Robin Williams plays it with rare restraint, and Gene Hackman? Totally owning it. The atmosphere, the set design, the costumes, it’s all gloriously over-the-top but never off-key. A sparkling, sharp, and heartfelt remake that thrives on performance. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-birdcage/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Tea and Sympathy
entry.content: 🎥 Tea and Sympathy, 1956 ⭐️ ★★★ Deborah Kerr and John Kerr give sensitive, nuanced performances. While it carries that unmistakable old-fashioned atmosphere, it never quite reaches the dramatic highs of Douglas Sirk. The film runs a bit longer than necessary, and starts to stretch in places, but the strength of its story holds steady. Delicate, daring, and quietly powerful. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/tea-and-sympathy/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Victim
entry.content: 🎥 Victim, 1961 ⭐️ ★★★★ Victim is a bold, ahead-of-its-time film that tackles its subject matter head-on. Dirk Bogarde delivers a quietly devastating performance, and the supporting cast, drawn from the finest of the British stage and screen, is uniformly excellent. A powerful, essential piece of cinema resplendent in its courage and craft. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/victim/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Ritz
entry.content: 🎥 The Ritz, 1976 ⭐️ ★★½ The Ritz is chaotic, loud, and uneven. If it weren't for Rita Moreno’s gloriously over-the-top performance, it might not be watchable at all. The film has a few genuinely funny moments, but they’re too scattered to give it real momentum. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-ritz/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Rebecca
entry.content: 🎥 Rebecca, 1940 ⭐️ ★★★★★ Rebecca is arguably Hitchcock's strongest early sound-era entry. From the first eerie shots of Manderley to the final blaze, this is unmistakably Hitchcock. The film bears his fingerprints in every frame, its meticulous cutting, haunting lighting, and elegant, psychological framing. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/rebecca/1/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning
entry.content: 🎥 Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning, 2025 ⭐️ ★★★½ Even as a standalone, this would’ve been a smash hit. The action is spectacular, the locations are stunning, and the set pieces are jaw-dropping. There’s strategy, suspense, and just the right dash of humor. Worth every cent of the ticket price and then some. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/mission-impossible-the-final-reckoning/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Three Musketeers
entry.content: 🎥 The Three Musketeers, 1973 ⭐️ ★★★½ Richard Lester’s take stands out for its sense of fun and camaraderie. The first part leans heavily on action, and while not all the fight sequences are particularly well executed. What really holds the film together is the star-studded cast, all clearly having a blast. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-three-musketeers-1973/1/ #FilmReview
